verses.verse: [a] Now the wife of one of the sons of the prophets cried out to Elisha, saying, “Your servant, my husband, is dead, and you know that your servant lived in fear of the LORD. His creditor is coming to take away his two sons to be his slaves.”
Elisha said, “What can I do for you? Tell me, what do you have at home?” She answered, “Your servant has nothing at home except for a flask of oil.”
He said, “Go around and borrow jars from all of your neighbors. Empty jars, and not too few of them.
Then go inside, and shut the door behind you and your sons. Fill all of those jars, and when a jar is full, set it to the side.”
So she left him, and she shut the door behind her and her sons who had brought her jars, and she kept pouring.
When all of the jars were full, she said to her son, “Bring me another jar.” He said, “There are no more jars,” and then the oil stopped flowing.
She went and recounted it to the man of God, and he said, “Go and sell the oil and pay your debt. You and your children can live on what is left over.”
One day Elisha traveled to Shunem.[c] There was an important woman there, and she insisted that he stop to eat. Whenever he passed by there, he would stop to eat.
She said to her husband, “Behold, this man who often visits us is a holy man of God.
We should prepare a small room on the roof, and place a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp in it for him. Then he can stay there when he visits us.”
One day he arrived, and he went into the room to lie down.
He said to Gehazi, his servant, “Call the Shunammite.” So he called her, and she stood before him.

He said to him, “Say to her, ‘You have put yourself through all this trouble for us. What could be done for you? Should we speak to the king or the commander of the army for you?’ ” She answered, “I dwell among my own people.”
He said, “Then what can be done for her?” Gehazi answered, “She and her husband are old, and they have no children.”
Elisha said, “Summon her.” He called her and she stood in the doorway.
He said, “You will embrace a son around this time next year.” She said, “No, my lord, O man of God. Do not lie to your servant.”
The woman became pregnant, and she had a son that time the next year, just as Elisha had predicted.
The child grew up, and one day he went out to his father who was with the reapers.
He said to his father, “My head! My head!” He said to a young man, “Carry him to his mother.”
He picked him up and brought him to his mother. He sat on her lap until noon when he died.
She went up and laid him on the bed belonging to the man of God. She closed him in the room and went out.
She called to her husband and said, “Please send me one of the young men and one of the donkeys so that I can hurry to the man of God and return.”
He said, “Why would you go today? It is not a new moon or the Sabbath.” But she said, “It is all right.”[d]
She saddled the donkey and said to her servant, “Lead on, and do not slow down for me unless I tell you.”
So she departed and came to the man of God on Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to Gehazi his servant, “Behold, it is the Shunammite.
Run to her and say to her, ‘Is everything all right? Is your husband well? Is your child well?’ ” She answered, “It is all right.”

When she reached the man of God on the mountain, she took hold of his feet. Gehazi approached to push her away, but the man of God said, “Leave her alone. Her spirit is in despair, but the LORD had hidden it from me and did not tell me.”
She said, “Did I ask for a son from my lord? Did I not say, ‘Do not lie to me.’ ”

Elisha said to Gehazi, “Gird up your loins, and take my staff in your hands, and go! If you meet anyone, do not greet him. And if anyone greets you, do not answer. Lay my staff upon the child’s face.”[e]
But the boy’s mother said, “As the LORD lives and as you live, I will not leave you.” So he got up and followed her.
Gehazi went on before them, and he laid the staff upon the child’s face, but there was no sound or response. He went out to meet him, and he said to him, “The child did not wake up.”
When Elisha arrived at the house, the child was lying dead upon his bed.
He went in, and he shut the door on the two of them, and then he prayed to the LORD.
He got up and lay upon the child, mouth to mouth, eyes to eyes, and hands to hands. He stretched himself out upon the child, and the child’s flesh grew warm.
He turned and walked back and forth in the room, and then he went and stretched himself out again. The boy sneezed seven times, and then the boy opened his eyes.
Elisha called for Gehazi, and he said, “Call this Shunammite.” He called her, and she came, and he said to her, “Take your son.”
She came in and bowed down, falling to the ground at Elisha’s feet. She then took her son and left.

Elisha returned to Gilgal, and there was a famine in the land. The sons of the prophets were sitting in front of him, and he said to his servant, “Set up the large pot and cook some soup for the sons of the prophets.”

One of them went out into the field to gather some herbs and he found a wild vine. He picked the wild gourds, filling his cloak. He cut them up into the pot of soup, although no one knew what they were.
When they poured out the soup for the men to eat, and they began to eat the soup, they cried out, “O man of God, there is death in the pot.” And they could not eat it.
He said, “Bring some flour.” He threw it into the pot and said, “Pour it out for the people to eat.” And there was nothing harmful in the pot.

A man came from Baal-shalishah, and he brought the man of God twenty loaves of barley bread from the firstfruits along with some heads of grain. He said, “Give it to the people so that they might eat.”
His servant said, “What? Should I place this before one hundred men?” But he said again, “Give it to the people to eat, for thus says the LORD: They will eat, and there will be some left over.”
He set it before them, and they ate, and there was some left over, just as the LORD had predicted.
